debate.para: Debate resumed from the 6th June (vide page 3726), on motion by Mr. Spender -

quote.para: That the following paper be printed: - South and South-East Asia - British Commonwealth Consultative Committee Conference, Sydney, May, 1950.

talk.start.para: .- This debate concerns a report by the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Spender) on the proceedings, so far as they can be published, of the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee Conference that was held in Sydney recently, and the House has in very general terms the report of what took place at that meeting. The subject-matter of this debate is related to the subject-matter of the debate that has just concluded and to other aspects of the situation in South-East Asia. For instance, the reasons given by the Minister for External Affairs in his statement in favour of the plan granting assistance to the countries of South-East Asia are in four groups. The first group relates to the humanitarian grounds for giving assistance; the second concerns the effect of such assistance upon world trade; the third deals with the need for obtaining political stability in this area; and the fourth sets out the necessity for removing conditions of misery and want and low standards in order that extremist and communistic philosophies which are a threat to democratic institutions shall not flourish. A number of questions is raised in the statement affecting the countries of South-East Asia and no doubt the debate on the statement will cover a wide field. I wish to make some observations that will deal mainly with the economic aspect of the matter. This conference was a. meeting of the members of the British Commonwealth, all of which were represented except South Africa. The location of the conference was fixed at Colombo because it was 'believed that the needs of South-East Asia,, economic and strategic, were such that the British Commonwealth conference should take place there. A conference was held, in Canberra in 1947 which dealt with the Japanese peace treaty, and finally it was agreed at the Prime Ministers' Conference early last year that the Colombo conference should be held. From that conference arose the decision to set up the consultative committee to which the Minister referred in his foreign affairs statement, the debate on which has just concluded. Even if the results of the conference may appear at this stage to be not definitive, the conference was undoubtedly a very valuable event. It is most important, since Pakistan, India and Ceylon have become members of the British Commonwealth, that the conference should be held in a regular way and should take place not only in London. I think that those observations will meet with the agreement of all honorable members in this House. I find in the Minister's statement general propositions with which I suppose nobody could possibly disagree. For instance at page four, he says -

quote.para: The problem of raising living standards in South and South-East Asia is of course vast and complex. It cannot be solved in some easy and immediate way by waving a magician's wand.

speech.para: Well, there is no magic wand available. Then the Minister says -

quote.para: Permanent solution can be found only if the basic facts are ascertained after careful inquiry and if realistic development programmes are prepared and co-ordinated.

speech.para: Again, that is correct. That is exactly what was reported in almost the same words by the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East of the United
Nations to which I shall refer directly. I agree with this statement -

quote.para: Die real significance of the conference lies pot-haps in the fact that representatives of the governments of seven Commonwealth countries have collectively considered the problem.

speech.para: That is good. Except one or two representatives they all are members of the United Nations and have considered this matter in relation to this particular area as members of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East, which the Minister referred to as Ecafe.

talk.start.para: - "Well, I am sorry-

- I have no' quarrel with that, but I prefer the full name of bl],. commission, which is the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East. It is very important that the House should consider the relationship between the activities of this commission and the work of the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee which has been set up. It is not accurate to suggest that any member on this side of the House ha? criticized the establishment of such ;> committee. On the contrary, they have claimed that the Colombo conference was originated by the Chifley Government and therefore ha.ve proved that we welcome all forms of Commonwealth co-operation. However, I do not think that such conferences go far enough. The members of the British Commonwealth should adopt the late Mr. John Curtin's plan, put forward in 1944 at the Prime Ministers' Conference of that year, to set up a permanent secretariat of the members of the British Commonwealth. Such a body would be of great assistance in following up the decisions of other British Commonwealth conferences. Mr. Curtin's suggestion was supported at that time by only the Labour Government of New Zealand. All the other British Prime Ministers objected to it. Time has proved the necessity for the establishment of such an organization to deal with all aspects of British Commonwealth co-operation. When conferences are summoned it is often impossible for senior Ministers to attend them, and in many cases the delegates are not Ministers at all. Therefore, they can only recommend to their governments. That means that no decisions can be made. which is precisely what happened at this conference. That is one of the difficulties inherent in relationships within the Commonwealth of Nations. It is the absence of a permanent organization which is a great weakness of the British Commonwealth. I know of no reason why the United Kingdom Commonwealth Affairs Department should be vested with the exclusive power of initiating and arranging these conferences. At some appropriate place, probably London, there should be a. permanent organization set up, of which the representatives of every part of thu British Commonwealth should be permanent members, so that the body could act as a continuing organization dealing with all problems, of which this is merely one example.

speech.para: The Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East is a United Nations body that was established, for the purpose of improving the economic position of backward areas throughout Asia and the Far East, including all the countries of South-East Asia. That commission has done, as the Minister said, a great deal of work in connexion with the problem of planning the economic, industrial and trade development of those areas. However, I fear that great duplication will occur unless that matter is very carefully safeguarded by the members of the British Commonwealth, including Australia. To illustrate that I refer the House to the annual report of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East for the period from July, 1948, to April, 1949. The membership of that body includes Australia, Burma, China, France, India, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Pakistan, the Philippines, Siam, Russia, the United Kingdom, and, most important of all, the United States of America. One of the recommendations of the conference of that body was that assistance be obtained from the United States. The conference said that it would be useless to continue its work without that assistance. I think that it is most important that the Australian Government should give full support to the existing United Nations organization, of which the United States of America is an active member. The organization required by the Minister is actually in existence, and it has made a number of reports, all of a preliminary character, no doubt, because the phrasing of the reports is like the phrasing of some of the recommendations of the British Consultative Committee.

talk.start.para: - "Who is the Australian member ?

- The meetings took place in one centre or another in SouthEast Asia, and the Australian representative is not a permanent representative. I was referring to the meeting of the commission held at Lapstone in New South Wales. I did not go through all the reports, but that conference dealt with the subject of "technical assistance". That phrase is like the blessed word " Mesopotamia ". Instead of deciding upon physical assistance to countries in need of it, the modern technique is to decide on technical assistance. The giving of such assistance means that in backward countries the people are provided with engineers to tell them that they need engineering plants, and educational authorities to tell them that they need educational schemes. That is a very prominent feature of this report. The House should consider carefully what is involved in the report. In this area assistance should be given of a more direct character if possible. The Chifley Government gave assistance to these countries in every way within its power.
- What kind of assistance?

- That Government established scholarships under which students of all those countries could attend Australian universities or agricultural institutions, and, in turn, Australians were selected to go to those other countries. We gave educational equipment for use in schools, we sent medical supplies and tried to give preference to those countries in connexion with the supply of flour and wheat. We restricted the sale of rice within Australia so that the whole of the Australian rice could go to Malaya and other countries in this area. During the war we took special account of the needs of those countries, and it was very satisfactory to myself, as a representative of the previous Government, to hear at the British Common wealth Conference iri London, the Prime Minister of Ceylon say that of all countries in the world with which Ceylon had had dealings the one which had rendered to it the most practical assistance during the war and post-war periods was Australia. That policy was not new, but it was our plain duty and we tried to carry it" out. I refer to the Economic Commission for Asia and the Ear East to make only two points. Its work is to cover trade, finance and technical assistance just as this committee is engaged in planning for technical assistance. I suggest to the Government that it is most important to avoid duplication, and that it should work actively in the existing organization of the United Nations. The representatives of the United States of America attend all its meetings, and the representatives of the economic bodies of the United Nations are men of high standing who will attempt to carry out the United States policy as enunciated by President Truman in the fourth point of the address delivered upon his election as president. The trouble about these bodies is that, although they suggest what ought to he done, great difficulty is often experienced in having their suggestions carried out. The report to which I have referred contains three recommendations. The first proposes the granting of technical assistance. The second contemplates an overall developmental plan that is to be considered later. The third recommendation is that interim measures be taken to provide emergency aid. The proposed measures are to be considered in London later this year. Agreement was reached at the Sydney conference to recommend that a maximum amount of fstg.8,000,000 be made available for technical assistance in South and SouthEast Asia. A Commonwealth bureau is i to be established at Colombo to assist in administering the technical assistance programme. That represents an important step and we welcome it, as everybody else who is interested in British Commonwealth relations must welcome it. However, the fact that requires emphasis is that the work is only in its preliminary stage. All that has been done so far has been to make recommendations to the governments of British Commonwealth countries. A further conference is to be held in London later. The objective is perfectly sound from whatever point of view it is examined. The wisdom of granting assistance to countries in South and South-East Asia is unquestionable. I agree that the idea is not new. The Charter of the United Nations declares explicitly that an improved standard of Jiving in those countries is desirable as a means towards preventing war. The report naturally emphasizes that aspect of the problem. Previous Australian governments have done likewise, and the Prime Minister of India, Mr. Nehru, also has stressed it. After all, this idea dates back to the agreement that was made between Mr. Churchill and President Roosevelt in the Atlantic Charter. One of the important ways of preventing war is to improve standards of living in areas such as South-East Asia.
- Yes. Peed them!
- Did the right honorable gentleman say " Freedom " ?
- No, I said "Peed them ".

- Well, the interjection aptly suggests a means of achieving one of the four freedoms - freedom from want. I have only one more comment to make about the Sydney conference. Prom press reports that were published at the time, it appeared that a great crisis had developed in the course of the conference, and severe criticism of the United Kingdom delegation was attributed to some representatives of other countries. That crisis ' lasted only for 24 hours, and agreement was reached in the end.
- Order ! The right honorable gentleman's time has expired.

.- I think that the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Spender) is deserving of congratulation on the statement that he has given to the House concerning the work of the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee on Aid to South-East Asia. J I was very pleasing to observe that the right honorable member for Barton (Dr. Evatt) apparently thought so highly of the Minister's work that he had no real criticism to make, but, instead, was complimentary about what had been attained. Indeed, if certain press reports that were published during the conference in Sydney were true, the result of the discussions is a great personal triumph for the Minister, and I think that, as it is his first essay in an international conference since his assumption of office, he is entitled to the respect and, I may add, the applause of this House. It is gratifying to learn that the right honorable member for Barton approves of consultative committees. Speaking for myself, and, I am sure, for all honorable members on this side of the chamber, I was particularly glad to hear him come out once more in favour of the establishment of some sort of organization such as an Empire secretariat. The right honorable gentleman gave the late Mr. Curtin the credit for that idea, but, without wishing to do any disrespect to the memory of a late and distinguished Prime Minister of this country, I think that it is only fair to say that that idea had germinated in quite a number of minds in the 1930's, and even before that time. There is ground for hope, however, that now that the process of consultative committees has been inaugurated, it will blossom forth in due course into what I am sure the majority of honorable members hope will come into being, namely, a permanent Empire secretariat. If what the right honorable member for Barton has said is expressive of the view of the Opposition, it gives all of us who .believe in closer Empire unity a great hope for a joint approach from this Parliament to other Empire countries in the future.

speech.para: There can be no question that in the matter of resisting communism in SouthEast Asia, the economic approach is wise. Those of us who have had some personal experience of the East will be the first to admit that, by European standards, the poverty, the overcrowding and the social conditions in those countries can only be described as appalling. Unless a corrective is applied fairly promptly, those countries will be an ideal breeding ground for communism. I suggest that we must take the long view, do more than merely make loans, provide food and supply technicians to South-East Asia. Honorable members should never forget that SouthEast Asia, as a theatre, concerns us more directly than it concerns any other English-speaking country. After all, it does not matter very much from the British viewpoint, so far. as the strategy of the United Kingdom is concerned, if Malaya is lost. It does not affect the vital security of France if the French lose Indo-China. It dees not matter greatly to the United States of America, from the standpoint of territorial integrity, what happens to those countries. But the territorial integrity of Australia is most vitally concerned. I am sure that it is quite unnecessary for me to remind the House of our predicament in 1942-48, but we must never forget that, in a future war, should Malaya, Indonesia and Indo-China fall to a hostile and aggressive power , the jeopardy of the people of this country will be heightened tenfold compared with what it was in the grave days of 1942. In the early years of World War II., the atomic bomb, long-range projectiles and other missiles were not being used. Now, with scientific developments, those deathdealing weapons may be hurled over greatdistances, and the people of this country, especially the women and children, would be placed in a plight they had never known before in our history.

Accordingly, I believe that, when we are considering the role of this country in respect of South-East Asia we are forced by the march of events and by geography into the position that Australia, in its own interests, if for no other reason, must assume British Commonwealth leadership in this sphere. To do that does not imply simply to make bold pronunciamentos and ambitious statements. We have to give some earnest of our intentions, and the world will not believe us, or credit us with sincerity, unless we come out frankly and boldly with the declaration that we are prepared to enter into military commitments in those areas. Many reasons may be adduced for a more ambitious policy on the part of this country in South-East Asia. Chief of them, I think, is that we have rather fallen into the error, irrespective of the political party that has been in power, of admonishing other countries by saying what we feel should be done here and there, whilst not showing any great determination to play a positive role in assuming our share of the responsibility for what ought to be clone. Regardless of the political parties to which- we belong, we are anxious to improve the stature of our country, and add to the weight of Australia in international councils, but unless we show the world that we are prepared to play a real part in, and take an increasing share of the responsibility for maintaining order in the countries that are closest to us, all our protestations will not receive much respect in the international forum. We certainly shall not get that assistance which, of course, is fundamental and imperative, from the United States of America unless we manifest a much greater determination to intervene, by force if necessary, in the south-eastern area than we have hitherto shown.

I beg of honorable members not to overlook another aspect of the matter. [ shall use a word that certainly in this post-war era has, to say the least, become unfashionable. There is the matter of the prestige of British peoples and, indeed, of all English-speaking peoples. The Anglo-American forces in the whole of the Far East, cannot afford to meet with any further reverses. 1 speak as one who, during World War II., served in that area, and suffered not only mental, but also physical indignities and saw in actual practice what the loss of white prestige involved. The Countries of the East are still ringing with the phenomenal and unexpected Japanese successes of 1942 and 1943, and in spite of the way in which the war was won, and the dramatic and unexpected termination of hostilities in 1945, the people of the East have seen the white races, especially the British, American and Australian forces, humiliated in a way which those who are living, I am sorry to say, will never forget. Furthermore, circumstances have conspired against us. Since 1945, the story from our viewpoint and from the British viewpoint has been one continual withdrawal. I am not saying that that policy was necessarily foolish and wrong. A good case can be made out to show that those withdrawals were inescapable, but the fact remains that the British have left

India and Burma, and the Dutch have virtually been cast out of Indonesia. The stage has been reached when, if the British Commonwealth wishes to maintain the territories that it still controls, from a security standpoint, in South-East Asia, it cannot afford to manifest any further signs of weakness. Again, I speak as one who has had between four and five years' experience in those countries, and I hope that honorable members will never forget that, in spite of what is said about the rapid changes that have taken place in the East, the mentality of Asiatic peoples, in the main, is still unchanged. They would regard any further sign of weakness as a defeat on our part, and would treat us with an increasing contempt.

I hope that when the British Commonwealth Consultative 'Committee resumes its deliberations in London, the Minister for External Affairs, and the Australian Government, whilst being diplomatic, conciliatory and helpful, will adopt a more forthright attitude. One can think of many examples. For instance, the situation in Malaya is of direct concern to this country. If that situation worsens, do not let us, as Australians, wait until the British Government pleads with us to send more help, even some troops ; but let us, I repeat, be forthright and more generous, and spontaneously co-operative by offering troops. You would get them by the thousands if you called for volunteers to-day. Similarly, as regards Indonesia, do not let us, when dealing with an untried government, be too diplomatic, as if we were dealing with a highly civilized Western European country. If Dr. Soekarno and his friends say that they want the whole of New Guinea, or even Western New Guinea, under an Indonesian Condominium, let us say without beating about the bush, "Hands off New Guinea. This is a direct sphere of interest for us, and something that is vital to our security. If the Dutch do not want to remain there, we are determined to hold it in the interests of our people ". In view of the gravity of these matters, let us also hesitate no longer to expand our defences, and thereby place ourselves in such a position that we can start to implement what I believe will be the historic destiny of this country: to lead the British Commonwealth in the whole of South-East Asia. This afternoon the right honorable member for Bradfield (Mr. Hughes) - that gallant old warrior, if I may say so - said that the Government's attitude could be rightly summarized in the words "feed them". I agree with that statement; but I go further and say that in our desire to help the peoples of South and South-East Asia we should set out not only to feed but also to lead them.

talk.start.para: .- Judging by the way in which the remarks that have just been made by the honorable member for Angas (Mr. Downer) were received by honorable members opposite, particularly the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Spender), I assume that he expressed the views of the Government. If that is so, the people of this country will have every reason to be genuinely disturbed so long as the determination of Australia's policy on international affairs rests in the hands of a Liberal government. The honorable member made a rather contradictory speech. Whilst he implied that the Government wanted to give economic aid to the people qf South and South-East Asia because of the appalling poverty that exists in those countries, at the same time he expressed the view that the Australian nation should become engaged in military ventures all over Asia. He said that Australia should take a leading part in this matter, as though Australia were a great world power, and could by military intervention restore order in those countries. Supporters of the Government criticized the waterside workers when they took action to prevent intervention in the Indonesian conflict. If, at that time, the Liberal Government had been in office we should probably have witnessed military intervention on the part of Australia in the Indonesian affair, and no one could imagine where that would have landed the Australian people. The Australian people desire that these matters shall be dealt with on a basis of negotiation and not by putting military forces into those countries as a prelude to dictating terms to them. The Australian people want to see a proper examination made of this problem in order to find out in what way this country can co-operate in overcoming these difficulties. Military intervention will not end poverty or the struggle of Asiatic peoples for decent living conditions.
- It would aggravate the difficulty.

- Yes. We need to evolve a plan that will establish conditions under which Australia can live in friendly relations with its neighbours. That should be the aim of the Government, which, however, is brandishing the big stick and saying to the Asiatic peoples that they must accept our ideas or we shall force them to do so. One of the most disturbing features of this debate is the implication in the Minister's speech that he is not going to have anything to do with the United Nations if there is any suggestion that the Soviet is going to be interested in what that organization does.
- That is completely untrue.

- If the Minister examines the remarks that he made this afternoon he will see that he implied that he would ignore the United Nations- in any action that it took in Asia because the Soviet, as a member of the United Nations, would be associated with such action. That is a foolish attitude. The Minister is endeavouring to by-pass the United Nations organization. He claims to have been responsible for the establishment of the committee dealing with the provision of economic aid in south and southeast Asian countries, whose work must necessarily overlap the work that has already been undertaken by the United Nations. There can be no doubt about that. Therefore, the activities of the Minister are mischievous in the extreme, and they could involve Australia in all sorts of difficulties.

speech.para: Why is not the Government realistic when it talks about the appalling misery that exists in Asiatic countries? Surely, it does not suggest that Australia is in a position to bear the major responsibility of improving the conditions of those peoples. We. can co-operate with the United Nations, which has been set up for this specific purpose, and with which the United States of America is associated. I recall that the Minister said that the work of the committee for whose establishment he has been responsible, could not be effective unless the United States of America was associated with it. Therefore, it is utterly ridiculous for us to talk about assisting the economies of those countries and at the same time, to. talk about embarking upon costly military intervention. The honorable member for Angas was applauded by the Minister when he made that statement. I should like to know exactly to what degree the Government proposes to intervene in the affairs of south and south-east Asian countries. It should first examine the situation to ascertain exactly what the problem is. The Minister took me to task this afternoon because, on a previous occasion, I referred to the fact that he and his supporters, when they were in Opposition, had said that the movement in Indonesia to get rid of Dutch control was a Communist and not a national movement. When they made those statements the Chifley Government referred the matter to the United Nations organization for a thorough investigation. As the result of those inquiries a peaceful settlement was reached. The Minister, when he was in opposition, declared that Dr. Soekarno, who is now President of Indonesia, was a Communist puppet, yet he now talks about being anxious to live on friendly terms with the Indonesians.

I agree with the statements that have been made with respect to Indonesian claims on West New Guinea. Australia's viewpoint on those claims should be clearly stated, and should be used as a basis of negotiations between the three parties concerned, namely, Indonesia, Australia and the Dutch authorities that control West New Guinea. I agree that Australia should not show any weakness in its approach to this matter ; but there is a vast difference between an attitude of reasonable negotiation and the idea that we should immediately occupy West New Guinea with military forces. Such action would prejudice any hope of settlement by negotiation. The same observation applies to the Malayan situation. That should be approached in the same way. However, some supporters of the Government have said that Australia should throw military forces into Malaya whether or not the British Government asks for such assistance. That statement was made by the honorable member for Angas. His remarks were ridiculous and dangerous. If every nation attempted to use force and to determine its own line of action in such circumstances, what would be the use of the United Nations organization which has been established with the primary object of dealing with problems of this kind? We have a lot to learn about the Malayan situation. The mere statement by the Minister that the trouble in that country is due to a Communist movement, does not satisfy me. The views that he expressed about the conflict in Indonesia were proved to be wrong. I think that he will admit that now. Likewise, he could be wrong in the reference that he has made to Malaya. It is quite true that the poverty that exists in Asian countries is appalling. Honorable members generally have admitted that fact in this debate. It says very little for the people who have been in control of those countries for many years if that poverty represents the best that they have been able to achieve. That fact is not a very good advertisement for those governments. I have ascertained, as best I could by reference to periodicals and articles that have been written on the subject, the facts of the situation that exists in south and south-east Asian countries. It appears that there must be a great deal of sympathy on the part of the local populations with those people whom the Minister has described as bandits. Otherwise, the latter could not have succeeded to the degree that they have succeeded in their operations. It would appear that the authorities in Malaya have failed to clear certain areas of lawless elements, because those elements have the sympathy of large numbers of the people in the localities concerned. Furthermore, there has been a lack of desire on the part of local communities in Malaya to co-operate with the police forces in their work. Why do local communities refuse to co-operate with the land forces under the control of the authorities in order to clear out these bandits ? The fact is, of course, that the people are not satisfied that any genuine effort has been or will be made to improve their conditions. The right honorable member for Bradfield (Mr. Hughes) said that we should feed them. There is nothing wrong with that attitude, but I say to him that Australia could hot bear the major part of that responsibility. I am amazed that although the present Government can find millions of pounds to fulfil its part of the plan to lift the living standards of peoples of Asian countries, it has declared, whenever members of the Opposition have asked it to take such action, that it has not sufficient funds to enable it to liberalize social services or to alleviate poverty in this country. That is the attitude of the Government. It should be prepared to say that it will at least expend as much for the purpose of alleviating distress in Australia as it proposes to expend to assist peoples in other countries.

What exactly is the position in Malaya ? Why does not the Minister, or his colleagues, inform us exactly of economic conditions in that country? According to my information, labourers in Malaya receive 2s. a day for ten hours' work whilst rice in that country costs 2s. per lb. That means that every Malayan labourer who receives that rate of pay is obliged to do a day's work in order to earn sufficient to buy 1 lb. of rice. Honorable members opposite should get down to the facts. It is quite evident that what these people need is not guns, bayonets and planes but a genuine effort on the part of other countries to feed them and to raise their living standards. How can we expect people who are able to earn only sufficient daily to buy 1 lb. of rice to be enthusiastic about maintaining a system which gives them no voice in the control of the affairs of their own country? I shall not be in order in dealing at length with this matter, because it is covered by an item that appears on the notice-paper. However, the Minister does not believe that the native peoples in any country are capable of achieving standards that would fit them to control their own affairs. For instance, he has refused to proceed with the Chifley Government's plan to set up a legislative council in New Guinea because that Government provided that the native population should have three representatives on that body. What is the position in this respect in Malaya? Native Malayans and Malayan-Chinese have no voice in the affairs of their country, because it is controlled by a legislative council that was set up by the British Colonial Office which determined that that body should consist of 22 members, sixteen of whom should be appointed by the British High Commissioner in Malaya and the remaining six should be elected, not by the native population, but by the members of the British community in Malaya. It should be said in fairness to the British community in that country that at the last election of the Legislative Council, only one-tenth of those British residents exercised the franchise. That fact shows that they disapprove of the present set-up. Why cannot the Government inform the Parliament of the changes that are proposed? Greater cooperation would be forthcoming from the native peoples if they were given an undertaking that they were to be given some share in the government of their own country. The Minister for External Affairs has been associated for some years, and still is associated, with the Goodyear Tyre and Rubber Company (Australia) Limited. He has been a director of the company. Although on the first occasion on which he was asked about the matter he denied that he was still a director, on the next occasion he said that he was connected with the firm as a director but only in a legal capacity.

talk.start.para: -Order! What has that to do with South and South-East Asia ?

- I am examining the Government's approach to this problem. My comments are pertinent to this discussion if I can demonstrate that a great many people are concerned, not about doing some good for the native peoples but about the preservation of their commercial interests and their capital investments in those areas. The Minister for External Affairs is connected with The Goodyear Tyre and Rubber Company (Australia) Limited which has extensive interests in south and south-east Asian countries. The defence of investments in those areas, whether they be owned by Britishers or Australians, is not worth the sacrifice of a single Australian life.

speech.para: There should be no need to talk about the use of military forces in Malaya, if our sole concern is to solve the economic problems of the people who live in that country. It is only natural to assume that they will readily co-operate with us in that task. Honorable members opposite say that Australia should maintain law and order in the countries of South and South-East Asia. Why should it be the responsibility of Australia to do so? Naturally we want law and order to be established in the countries that are near to us, but Australia is not in a position to set itself up as the policeman of the Pacific. Yet that is the role that this Government proposes shall be played by this country. The only way to deal with the problem is to refer it to the United Nations and to seek the co-operation of the great powers of the world in solving it. Surely, if all the international declarations - the Atlantic Charter, the Charter of Human Rights and other solemn undertakings entered into by the great nations of the world - mean anything, they mean that the signatory nations will co-operate in the handling of problems of this kind. No matter how warlike some honorable members opposite may be, Australia is not in a position to set itself up as the policeman of the Pacific.

talk.start.para: - Why not?

- The honorable member for Hume (Mr. Charles Anderson) asks "Why not?" The people of Australia are best able to answer that question. They were evidently not fully aware of the risks that they took when they elected this Liberal-Australian Country party coalition Government to control their affairs. Among the members of the Liberal and Australian Country parties are men who are so war-minded that they can be classified as war-mongers. They want Australians to go into these areas-

- I rise to order. The statement of the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) that members of the Australian Country party are warmongers is objectionable to me and to my colleagues. I ask for a withdrawal and an apology.

- The honorable member for Canning (Mr. Hamilton) regards the expression as offensive and has asked for its withdrawal. I ask the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) to comply with his request. ,

- If you can recollect my words, Mr. Speaker, you will remember that I said that among the Liberal and Australian Country parties are men who are so war-minded that they can be regarded as war-mongers.

- Order ! I have asked for the withdrawal of the words that the honorable member for Canning has characterized as objectionable. The Standing Orders provide that an honorable member must withdraw words to which another honorable member has taken exception.
- In deference to you, Mr. Speaker, I withdraw the words, although I am rather dubious about the ruling.
- The honorable member may challenge it if he wishes to do so.
- I shall probably do so at the appropriate time.
- The time is now, or never.

- I would not say "never", Mr. Speaker, because there may be other opportunities for me to do so. However, with due deference to the tender feelings of some honorable members opposite, I merely say that they aim to introduce a system of compulsory military training and to impose conscription on the youth of this country for the purpose not of safeguarding the shores of Australia, but of providing a military force which can be sent to countries adjacent to Australia in order to protect their investments. Their attitude on this matter has been clearly defined in this debate.
- Order ! The honorable member's time has expired.

. - The honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) has made a speech which to any returned ex-serviceman can only - to put it mildly - be regarded as lamentable. He has been a fighter all his life, but he has never had to fight with anything but his tongue. I realize that he is an idealist; but, unfortunately, he is a muddle-headed idealist who occupies a very high place in this community. Once again my mind goes back to Changi -

speech.para: The honorable member was one of the leaders of this country and one who held high office in the Parliaments of the Commonwealth. He did not realize as he should have done the danger that confronted this country. I, like the honorable member for Angas (Mr. Downer), agree that the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Spender) is to be congratulated upon having tried, on behalf of the Government, to effectuate a high ideal in the appointment of the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee. I agree that that committee may be subsidiary to the committee appointed by the United Nations; but when all is said and done we only have to add the United States of America to the existing representation on the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee and the composition of that body will be precisely the same as that of the committee appointed by the United Nations. In this world of human hopes and fears the honorable member should realize that it is of no use for a man to be an idealist unless he is also a realist. His speech to-night may have revealed his sincere idealism, but there was no note of realism in it. He knows nothing about Malaya, which is one of the most important countries in South-East Asia. All he did was to criticize the actions of the British administrators whose work has very largely made it possible for him and for many of his fellow Australians to grow to manhood in peace and quietness. The insurrection in Malaya is not a national uprising. The Malayan Chinese, the Malays and anybody who has been in Malaya will tell him that the trouble has come to that country because the police and the military forces were not allowed to do what they should have done to preserve law and order. A Malayan Chinese who lives in one of the outlying villages and is threatened by bandits does not know whether they will finally overthrow the whole economy of Malaya and will naturally think, "I must pay the bandits a tribute or give them food because I am not quite sure that in the long run they will not win out ". If we intend to give economic aid and technical assistance to the countries of South-East Asia we must first establish law and order where law and order doe? not at present exist. That cannot be done merely by a display of idealism. If law and order are to be upheld, there must be a police force, especially in Malaya, where alien Chinese leaders control the bandits and commit murder almost unchecked. The murders that are committed in that country are the work not of the British High Commissioner for South-East Asia as the Communists recently alleged in Sydney, but of the foreign-controlled bandits. Unfortunately, the honorable member for East Sydney is prone to repeat in this House, almost word for word and syllable for syllable., propaganda issued by those whom the Australian Labour party equally with the Government is now decrying. The trouble in Malaya has arisen 'because the British authorities in that country have not taken sufficiently strong action since the termination of the war to bring the bandits to justice, and because persons who have no knowledge of the country have too often been appointed to administrative and police posts. When the first disturbances occurred a man who had been head of the Palestine police force was appointed to direct operations against the insurgents. Though he was a courageous man, he did not know the East and he was tactless in his dealings with the people of the country. According to the Intelligence Digest, sixteen leading members of the police force, twelve of whom had had at least twenty years' experience in Malaya, resigned since that appointment was made. The British authorities in Malaya seem to act on the assumption that nobody can -land arms and equipment on the const, of Malaya during the monsoon season. Somebody should remind them of what happened on the -7th December, 1941. All the mistakes that were made in pre-war years are being repeated. Now that an officer has been selected to command the military forces who has had experience of jungle fighting in Burma, I hope that rapid progress will be made towards ending the reign of terrorism and banditry, ensuring the peace and prosperity, not of the capitalists, but of the people who live in that country - the Malays and the Malayan Chinese. Why is there a full brigade of Malays in the Malayan army? Why have the Malays joined the police force? The " Ferret " force consists of Gurkhas, Malays and British volunteers. Unfortunately the authorities brought Dyak blacktrackers from Sarawak towns instead of the blacktrackers from the jungles of Borneo. If the honorable member for East Sydney would go to Malaya, live in that country for a little while and talk to the Malays and the Malayan Chinese, he would realize that what he has said in this House to-night is utter nonsense. If he goes to that country I trust that he will emulate the British Minister for War and have his photograph taken to demonstrate that he was out with a jungle fighting force. As everybody knows a man must be fighting fit before he can go on a jungle patrol.

talk.start.para: - Bate.- He would need to be trained for three months.

- He would need six months' training to fit him for that task. The honorable member for East Sydney is probably a brave man, but he would not be fit to go on a jungle patrol without adequate training. Unfortunately, the police have .been handicapped in their endeavours by being asked to carry out orders that they knew it was perfectly useless to attempt to carry out. However, we hope that those conditions have changed and that peace, and progress will return to Malaya, because that country is one of the most vital places in South-East Asia. The same description applies to Indo-China and Burma. If we desire to help those people about whom the Opposition speaks so glibly, the first necessity is to give them food. The honorable member for East Sydney would apparently say that if there were cannibals in South-East

speech.para: Asia the best thing to do would be to send .them more missionaries.

In order to enable those countries to grow more food it is necessary to establish law and order in rice-producing areas. Burma was formerly one of the biggest rice-producing areas in Asia, hut since the Burmese gained national independence the production of rice has fallen by, I believe, from 50 to 60 per cent. The valley of the Mekong River in Indo-China is another great riceproducing .belt. All the rice that we grow in the Riverina is just chicken feed compared with the rice that will be grown in Indo-China and Burma when peace, law and order are restored to those countries. Therefore, the first essential, as has already been stated in this House, is not to go rushing in, as the honorable member for East Sydney has suggested, but to assist in establishing law and order so that governments can operate in those areas. When proper government hae been established, as has been done and is being done in Malaya, the task will be to develop the people of the areas so that they can gradually take over more and more control of their own affairs. It would be of as much use to sponsor a kindergarten pupil as a candidate for membership of this House as it would be to allow undeveloped peoples to have complete control of their own affairs. Things have to be done gradually whether in respect of technical or economic assistance, education or the art of government. If honorable members went to Malaya, which country the honorable member for East Sydney apparently has not visited if we are to judge by his remarks, and saw the work that has been and is being done there by the British administration in regard to the educational system, they would be proud. If they drove along the roads they would see in almost every village and native kampong a neat school with a fine playing field alongside it and with Malay children coming out in their nice white robes with blue sashes. That is one of the finest sights in Malaya, and it is also one of the greatest tributes that could be paid by any country to the administration of another country. A great deal of the work that has been done by the British administration will con tinue to bear fruit when the Malayans reach the stage of self-government.

India, Pakistan and Ceylon, which are now independent nations of the British Commonwealth, will continue to develop in the spirit of the old British Empire. They will develop gradually as we did. The succession of events is that a country gains its independence and then steps forward under the aegis of the British Commonwealth. It does not matter whether people call it the British Empire or the British Commonwealth of Nations, because it still operates with the underlying spirit of the old British Empire whose people went out into the far corners of the earth, established administrations and helped native peoples with health measures and educational and technical assistance until they were independent and could stand on their own feet and take an independent place in the British Commonwealth of Nations and finally in the United Nations. One of the greatest compliments that we could pay ourselves would be to remind ourselves of that fact. The consultative committee which the Minister has played a big part in founding is carrying on that work and spreading it out in wider and wider ripples into the great pool of the world. Yet people like the honorable member for East Sydney say, in effect, that all we are trying to do is to be as greedy and grasping as possible. No more nonsensical and vituperative argument has ever been advanced in this House, and I hope that honorable members who believe as the honorable member for East Sydney does in that respect will take the earliest opportunity of going to and seeing for themselves some of the good work that has been done in Malaya, and will then pass fair judgment upon it. Ignorance of these matters is not a valid excuse.

The honorable member for East Sydney also criticized other honorable members for suggesting that we should take bigger responsibilities upon our shoulders. Australia has been sheltered by Britain from the time when the first settlement was established in the Sydney area, and it has been only since the last war that Australia has really grown to full stature and capable of taking on its shoulders responsibilities that were previously carried by the Mother Country. In that respect Malaya is our front door step. The countries of South-East Asia are partly our responsibility, and I hope that the Minister and the other members of the committee formed in Sydney will be very successful, remembering of course all the time that it is of no use to have ideals unless we are also strong enough to command respect. "We on this side of the House advocate a proper defence system in order that we may be strong enough to command respect, but not in order to attack those who are weaker than we are. We must shoulder these responsibilities. During this debate very few suggestions have come forward about how we should shoulder them. I suggest to the Minister once again that it is no good merely to offer money to the countries of South-East Asia. Anybody will accept money. It is also no good to try suddenly to mechanize an eastern country. It is necessary to proceed gradually. The people of those countries have their ancient methods of life, such as water wheels with buckets or old tin. cans on the end of a lever. The way to help them is to send them pumps that will make it easier for them to irrigate their fields. As soon as we have improved their methods of irrigation by providing them with hand pumps we can provide them with mechanical pumps, then replace their ancient ploughs with modern ploughs. But it is wrong to think that we can help them by suddenly supplying them with a lot of bulldozers. If we did that we should throw 90 per cent, of the people on the land out of employment. It is impossible to lift these people all of a sudden out of the twelfth or the fourteenth century and dump them down in the middle of the modern mechanized age. Therefore I hope that technical assistance will proceed along gradual lines just as education proceeds in this country from the kindergarten by successive stages up to the university standard. I hope also that while we are educating those countries we shall also be able to develop with them friendships based on co-operation and a realization that in the past the British people in South-East Asia have done a fine job and that we wish to do an even better job under modern conditions. But for goodness sake let us get out of the state of mind that the honorable member for Ea3t Sydney evinced in his speech to-night.

talk.start.para: .- I consider that it is a truism to say that this country was never in more danger than it is in at this moment. This country has a huge territory. It is the largest island and the smallest continent in the world, but it is occupied by only 8,000,000 people whose comparative defencelessness is perfectly obvious, not only to the peoples of the world, but also to ourselves if we study for one moment just how our people are distributed in our territory and just how little we can do in our own defence. Almost the whole of our 8,000,000 people are jammed in a narrow area between a mountain range on the eastern side of the continent and the sea. We have 6,000 miles of northern coastline between Cairns, in Queensland, and Geraldton, in Western Australia, occupied by only 10,000 people. We have a territory which we call the State of Western Australia that covers about 1,000,000 square miles, and north of Carnavon there are only about 5,000 white people occupying 500,000 square miles of the most vulnerable portion of Australia. There are 12,000 people in the Northern Territory from Alice Springs to Darwin. So, while we talk about what help we can give to other nations, we should really consider the help that we ourselves might require from other peoples who would be disposed for various reasons, altruistic, utilitarian, materialistic or other, to come to our aid when we required them to do so. Fortunately, we survived World War II. because we were able to shelter under the protecting wing of the American eagle. American aid was indispensable to our continued existence as a citadel of European civilization. Such aid might be even more essential in the days ahead of us because our position has not improved with the passage of time. The peoples with whom we are so closely associated are themselves in grave difficulties. Two world wars saw the white races doing a fairly successful job of exterminating each other at a time when the non-white races were increasing rapidly.

speech.para: One has only to look at the tremendous increase of the population of the nearest and biggest territory to us, the island of Java, to realize the population growth that has taken place. In the space of about two generations the population of that area has increased from about 4,000,000 to 70,000,000. In the same period our population has increased from 3,000,000 to 8,000,000. More people are born in India every year than we have in the whole of Australia to-day. What happens in India, of course, happens also in China and in other countries with populations of comparable size. We have an obligation to do all that we can to help other people. I do not disagree with the Minister's statement, in which he said that the problem of raising the living standards in South and South-East Asia is immense and complex. He said that it cannot be solved in some easy and immediate way by waving a magician's wand. I do not think that we can solve the problem at all, because of its vastness and complexity. The Minister has told us that a technical advisory committee that has been established as a result of the Sydney conference is to expend £8,000,000 on technical assistance to 500,000,000 people. That means a contribution by us of 5d. a head of those people. Of course it would not be distributed on a population basis, but even so our proportion of that £8,000,000 would be insignificant. That does not mean that we should not try to do something for them. But I believe that we should be deluding ourselves if we considered that a contribution of £8,000,000 by the seven British Commonwealth countries, the representatives of which met in Sydney, would make any material difference to the conditions of large numbers of people in nearby Asiatic countries. 1 am not so sure that the countries that we should like to help in the fight against communism - because our objective in helping these countries is partly humanitarian and partly to effect an insurance against the risk of the spread of communism - will be as appreciative as we should like them to be for any assistance we might give. We of the occidental races make a great mistake in trying to think in terms of what the oriental will do. The occi dental mind cannot always fathom the oriental. I was astonished recently to find just how blatant certain representatives of the Indonesian Government are on the subject of communism. On the third of this month I saw a report in a newspaper to the effect that Dr. Hatta, who is the Prime Minister of Indonesia, told his Parliament, in closed session, that there were no big obstacles in the way of Indonesian recognition of the Indo-Chinese Viet-minh leader, Ho Chi-minh, who is a rebel against the authority of the. Government of his country and a Communist puppet. Ho Chi-minh has not overthrown the lawful government of his country, yet the Indonesian Government is thinking of recognizing him, and Dr. Hatta is reported to have said that recognition depended on whether it would be useful to Ho Chi-minh and, at the same time, bring no difficulties to Indonesia. This opportunistic attitude on the part of the rulers of Indonesia indicates that whatever assistance Australia may give to that country may ultimately benefit the Communists who may take over Indonesia in the future just as the aid which America poured into Nationalist China went to the Communist forces and was used to expel all traces of association with the western world from that country. I am not as optimistic as are the Minister and those who think with him that in giving aid to these countries, Australia will be casting its bread upon the waters and it will return a thousand fold.

talk.start.para: - After many months.

- After many months or a few days. At any rate, the Chifley Government tried that procedure. It gave assistance in the way of scholarships. It gave financial aid to Asiatics people in varying degrees but that did not stop the downward rush of Asiatic communism. I consider that the Government should concentrate on the continuous introduction to this country of as many people of our own choosing as we can absorb. A person's salvation depends, according to our Christian teaching, upon that person's own effort. Nobody can save a man's soul if he does not want it to be saved and no nation can save another if it does not take steps to ensure its own safety before worrying about other people. I am haunted by the fear that a third world war might occur at any time in the approximate or remote future. There is nobody who does not fear that a third world war might eventuate. Many people are convinced that it will eventuate. Another world war would not solve the problem of communism. Paradoxically it might result both in the defeat of Russia and in further Communist infiltration of the western and Asiatic worlds. In "World War II. Russia suffered 20,000,000 casualties, but after the war, in spite of that material and physical damage, communism spread outside Russia's borders to the Oder in Germany, down to the Dardanelles, and across to the Adriatic Sea. Tito's defection has relieved the strain on the West but there is not the slightest doubt that if he had remained in association with Russia the western world would have been in difficulties in the Adriatic Sea, the Mediterranean Ocean and the Aegean Sea. A third world war could easily result in overwhelming disaster for the races that are of European origin. The rays of a setting sun are flickering now over the western world and if they grew dimmer western civilization might be extinguished for a decade or two, or for centuries. The phenomenal growth of Asiatic nationalism combined with Asiatic communism makes one wonder what will happen, not so much to us, as to our children and our children's children in this country. Nobody can foretell the future with any certainty. Australians have every reason to be at least a little apprehensive no matter what they may do and how good their intentions may be to solve the problems that arise at home and abroad.

speech.para: It has been said during the debate that the late Mr. John Curtin, when he was Prime Minister, took a proposal for an Empire secretariat to a conference of Commonwealth Prime Ministers in London. That is true. But it is also true that he received no support for his proposal. Canada and South Africa would not have anything to do with it; New Zealand was indifferent to it; and the United Kingdom Government could see little of value in it. The United King- dom Prime Minister at that time was Mr. Churchill, who was the head of a National Government. No political party in the United Kingdom wanted the Empire secretariat that Australia advocated although the importance of having such a secretariat! ait that time could not be gainsaid. The proposal had the support of the political party of which Mr. Curtin was the leader. The consultative council which the Minister proposes to set up may do a lot of good work but the only machinery that has been provided for its operation so far is machinery for collecting facts concerning the economic plight of the nations it is desired to help. At a later stage, presumably when this information is collated in September of this year for the conference in London, assistance will be sought from the United States of America and perhaps the participation of that country in this scheme may be secured. But the United States of America has a foreign policy which is dictated by those who live on its eastern seaboard. The people who live on the western coast of America have very little influence on the foreign policy of their country, which is directed, as it was during World War II. and as it has been since that country emerged from its isolationist period, towards making Europe secure against further Russian attacks. Australia is interested in the development of Asiatic communism, but to America that is a secondary consideration, as was everything in the Pacific zone during World War II. The policy of America during World War II. was to beat Hitler first. The- American Government considered that the problems of the Pacific would be resolved after Hitler had been defeated. American aid is being concentrated in Europe and little is being given to the Pacific despite what the Minister has said about the favorable reception which Mr. Dean Acheson gave to the representations of Mr. Ernest Bevin following the conclusion of the Sydney talks. America has contributed little or nothing in the Pacific so far and American safety does not impel it to do more than concentrate on that area of activity which is bounded by the Philippines on the south and the Aleutian

Islands in the north. It is to be hoped that America will come into the plan because, if it does not, there will be no hope of the plan succeeding as none of the Commonwealth countries can afford the expenditure that might make it succeed. .The United States of America is spending a lot of money in Europe in Marshall Aid but that aid is a diminishing quantity. As Europe emerges more and. more successfully from the struggle to survive and to revive its industries, American aid will diminish, and it will not be poured out in Europe or the Pacific in greater quantities but will be dis- tributed in smaller quantities as time goes on. Consequently, I am not very hopeful that Australia can obtain very much assistance from the United States of America.

Arguments in this debate have started from the premise that non-Communist Asiatic countries could be helped to remain non-Communist. I am not sure that that can be done. I believe that in the next six or seven years there will be further Communist successes in Malaya and Si am, and perhaps in Indonesia and all that territory which at present is either nominally or actually non-Communist. For instance, Communist forces are only about 20 miles from Manila. Communist forces and rebel forces known as the " Hicks " have been fighting the Government forces and they are so strong that the Government's authority does not extend much more than 25 miles from the national capital. VicePresident Barkley of the United States of America said in a special address to Congress a short time ago that America might have to re-occupy certain countries from which it had withdrawn its forces. Everybody knows that he meant that American forces would be invited to return by the President of the Philippines because his government was unable to maintain or assert its authority. I believe that a substantial proportion of the population of Indonesia and the Philippines is composed of Japanese collaborators of the World War II. period and that there is as much corruption in those countries as there was in nationalist China, a state of affairs that seems natural enough to a lot of the people who live in them but is viewed with abhorrence by Australians, who believe that governments that are founded on corruption cannot last. The problem is one not only of assisting non-'Communist forces but also of establishing governments that are honest and above corruption and, therefore, do not cause the very distressed conditions on which communism grows. Communism, with all its faults, which are numerous, has certain virtues and it seems to impose discipline and to make a lot of people who were corrupt refrain from doing the things they had been in the habit of doing. Of course, corruption of another sort creeps into Communist countries and that is usually disastrous.

I shall conclude with the words of Sir Oliver Goonetilleke, Prime Minister of Ceylon, who was in Australia during the war period on behalf of his country. Australia assisted him very much in the procurement of supplies and he is a friend of Australia. I am sure that he wants this consultative committee to function, but his expectations are not great.

The honorable member for Melbourne (Mr. Calwell) said that very often the occidental mind could not gauge correctly what the oriental mind was thinking. - It cannot be established that Australian have ever been warmongers. This country has been engaged in two great wars because its citizens have volunteered to keep the enemy away from its shores. The honorable member for East Sydney owes the position that he has in this country, and his peaceful occupancy of it, to the men he spoke so much against a few minutes ago. Had it not been for them he would not have had the opportunity of making the speech that he made in this House. Australia is a great democracy and democracy gives great privileges to the people. As a corollary, it demands great sacrifices. A large number of Australians have never been wanting in making sacrifices in time of war, but no one in this House or elsewhere should be allowed to call the Australian people warmongers. If any one insults the fighting forces in that manner in this House, some honorable member on the Government side will rise and speak for those men who are not here and are therefore not able to speak for themselves. After the honorable member for Angas has said that we must be firm with the teeming millions overseas, the honorable member for East Sydney said that the honorable member for Angas advocated sending forces straight away to fight in Malaya. He said that plenty of Australians would volunteer to go to Malaya.
- What is the difference?

- We realize that Malaya is the doorstep of Australia. If we are not prepared to send men out of Australia to protect this country, what country can w.e expect to do the job for us? It is not a matter of trying to protect British traders in the islands, it is a matter of not allowing the Communists to capture the Malayan Peninsula and from that vantage point later to pour into Australia. The men whom the honorable member for East Sydney spoke against were the ones who saved Australia from invasion. The honorable member for East Sydney is always anxious to speak about Australia's request to America for assistance; but, with the greatest respect for the Americans, who. did a marvellous job during the war, I claim that had it not been for the 8th Division of the Australian Imperial Force holding up the Japanese on the Malayan Peninsula for seven weeks, we should not have had the opportunity of fighting the Coral Sea Battle. The Japanese would have invaded this country, and although eventually we should have put them out, the damage and devastation that they had done to the country in the meantime would have been with us for generations. These things are said against men who-
- Nobody said anything against those men.
