talk.start.para: - I shall move on to that subject. In the Malayan Peninsula at present the terrorists are practically in charge. They come out from their secret depots in the jungle by night and it is difficult to get them into the open by day to fight them. We know how hard it is to fight in the jungle, because no one knows where the enemy may be. The honorable member for East Sydney said that there are two sides to tl is matter. That is correct. There is the side of the Communist and terrorist, and there is the side of democracy. On which side are the members of the Opposition? On which side is the honorable member for East Sydney? When that question is answered we shall know what our position is. I was pleased to hear the honorable member for Chisholm (Mr. Kent Hughes) make the statement about schools having been established during the British occupancy of Malaya, and about the population being reasonably well treated. I was impressed, when in Malaya, with the fact that wherever I went I would see children coming from school, and that the juvenile population appeared to be remarkably happy. Of course there were some very sad cases, but then there are very sad cases in the districts of Redfern, which the honorable member for East Sydney represents. Despite the fact that a Labour Government has been in power in the Commonwealth for eight years and in New South Wales for nine years, there are still sad cases in Redfern. British occupancy of Malaya has been of great benefit to that country. Before the

speech.para: British went to the Straits Settlements there was very little food grown for the people. To-day there are several methods in use for growing rice and other food, which have been observed by tourists. When something like peaceful conditions again obtain and Malaya is rid of the menace of communism, still more food will be grown for the population. Without proper leaders the Malayans were ruled by the law of the jungle. To-day there is some kind of civilization there, and when one moves through Malaya one sees everywhere happy people; perhaps just as large a percentage as can be seen in the metropolitan areas of Australia.

The honorable member for East Sydney said that the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Spender) had not been willing to set up the Legislative Council for the Territory, of Papua-New Guinea, for the establishment of which legislation was enacted during the regime of the previous Government. I think he said that that was because it was provided that three natives should be members of the council. If honorable members read the record of what happened while the Labour party was in office, they will find that when this bill in respect of the Legislative Council of Papua-New Guinea was placed before this House it did not provide that the members to be elected should be required to take the oath of allegiance. In other legislative councils in the British Empire it is necessary that the oath of allegiance shall be taken. Some honorable members here to-day will recall that when the bill was before the House I pointed out to the Minister at that time in the House, who was not the honorable member for East Sydney, that there was no provision for the taking of the oath of allegiance. I was given a guarantee that after the bill had been returned from another place a provision for the taking of the oath of allegiance would be inserted in it. When the bill again came before this House the prescribed oath had been changed. It was not the oath of allegiance, but merely an' oath of service. If the Minister for External Affairs has some reason for not setting up the Legislative Council for Papua-New Guinea at the present time,

I suggest that his reason is quite legitimate. Nobody knows what would have happened had the previous Government set up the Legislative Council without the oath of allegiance being required of its members. The honorable member for Adelaide (Mr. Chambers), who was handling the bill at that time, said that he would see that provisions for taking the oath of allegiance should be put in it, and I am confident that that will be done.

talk.start.para: - I think that that must be done by legislation.

- Then it should be done. No government should put into that Legislative Council anybody who does not take that oath, because goodness knows whom they might be or from where they might have come. I rose only to make a protest against the remarks of the honorable member for East Sydney. I believe that they will be deplored by every honorable member of this House, as well as by the people of this country.

.- With some of the arguments of the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) I disagree strongly. I remember his speech very clearly, and I believe that nobody here has any right to say that he made any reference whatever, either complimentary or otherwise, to those killed in the last war. It is a vicious distortion of his words by the honorable member for Mallee (Mr. Turnbull) to say that there was any such reference.
- I did not say " those killed ".

- If the honorable member has the decency to look tomorrow at the Hansard " flat " containing his speech, he will see that what I have said is correct. I think that the Minister is to he congratulated on the work of the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee Conference in Sydney, also upon its decision that Australia shall make a contribution to the restoration of order and perhaps of living standards in Asia. The honorable member for Chisholm (Mr. Kent Hughes) asked for realism. I certainly think that there is no field of politics in which we should try. to look at the facts steadily and see them whole more so than in the field of foreign policy. The policy of Dr. Soekarno, the situation in Indonesia and the claims of the Indonesian leaders to the. western half of New Guinea, to which references have been made in the course of this debate, deserve to be studied in the same realistic light. Dr. Soekarno is not in a position even to maintain order in the United States of Indonesia. He is certainly not in a position to take the territory of western New Guinea by force. I do not advance that statement in order to minimize the force of his claim, but I think that if we consider the situation in realistic terms, we must recognize that he is making demands that he could not possibly translate into facts. We should consider one fact about this situation and, indeed, the situation of all Asiatic national movements. Every movement of that character has always tended to break into two wings - a modernizing wing and another consisting of men such as those who were called extremists in India in the early part of this century. Tilak was an extremist and, in some senses, Gandhi was an extremist. The term in this connexion has no reference to militancy. It refers to an extreme repudiation of Western civilization, and very often that repudiation of the West is prosecuted in the name of religion. In India, the extremists, looking back to an imaginary golden age of Hinduism, repudiated the ideals of many Indians who, like Nehru to-day, demanded the modernization of their State. The extremist wanted not only to reject Western rule but also to repudiate Western ideas. The tenuous hold of Dr. Soekarno and his friends upon the reins of government in Indonesia is threatened by an extremist movement: It ils a religious movement of the Moslems, who are making extreme territorial demands. They have threatened Soekarno, and he has had to fight them with such armed forces as he has at his disposal. Consequently, I believe that his claim upon western New Guinea may be regarded as an attempt to outbid those who are opposed to him and who are making similar claims. He fears that, if he appears to the Indonesian people as a leader less militant and less extreme in his demands than those who are threatening him, he may lose some of their support. Therefore, I think that Soekarno's claims are a sign of his internal weakness rather than a sign of strength on his part.
- I do not think that the Moslem movement has made any -claim to territory in New Guinea.

- No ; but it is making extreme claims for Indonesian nationalism, and Soekarno believes that he may outbid them for the support that he is endeavouring to gain by claiming New Guinea territory for Indonesia.

speech.para: We can easily fall into the error of making unreal contrasts in attempting to decide the relative importance to us of Europe and Asia. Historically, we have never been threatened from Asia unless Europe has been in turmoil. It is a truism to say that, had Great Britain not been distracted by the outbreak of war in Europe in 1939, Japan would not have struck in 1941. It is realistic to recognize also that the sharpest threat to us from Asia would come if Europe were to set itself afire again. Therefore, I deprecate any suggestion that we should be more concerned about Asia than about Europe. We must make our contribution to the restoration of sanity in Europe and to the adoption of a firm policy in that area. I am certain that, in the event of another world conflict, the powers upon which we should rely - Great Britain and the United States of America - would be far more concerned about the European situation than they would be likely to be concerned about the Asiatic situation. Once again, Asia would be secondary in importance to Europe.

The honorable member for Chisholm adopted a realistic line of analysis when he suggested a limitation of the value that we place upon the decisions of the Sydney conference. I do not suggest that he was critical of that conference, but he reminded us that technical aid is not nearly so important to the restoration of living standards in Asia as is the re-establishment of order in certain vital food-producing regions. I believe that the main value of the Sydney conference could very well rest in the possibility that it will provoke the United States of America into helping in the reconstruction of South-East Asia when it realizes that other powers are willing to shoulder some of the burdens of world recovery. Such a result proceeding from that conference would be of great value. If we look at the situation realistically, we must admit that reconstruction can be achieved only in two ways. The first, which would involve a short-term plan, would require the United States of America to throw into Asia economic aid equal to that which has been thrown into Europe. That would be too much to expect. A massive effort of that nature would be needed to establish decent living standards in South-East Asia. The second way would be, as the honorable member for Chisholm has said, to restore production in the Irrawaddy V.alley and the Mekong Valley. The Irrawaddy Valley and the rest of Burma exported 4,000,000 metric tons of rice to other Asiatic countries in 1939. The Mekong Valley was not nearly so important; nevertheless it produced about 1,000,000 metric tons of rice in that year. Those vast quantities of food would transform the Asiatic situation if they were available to-day. However, the most recent figures that I have seen show that rice is being exported from Burma only at onesixth of the pre-war rate.

A significant fact that greatly impresses me is that -the forces that are endeavouring to prevent the recovery of Asia, whose activities in Malaya have been discussed during this debate, are concentrating upon the pressure points in the East. I consider that Malaya is only a secondary field for their activities. The sowing of disruption in Burma is vital to their cause. A similar programme in Indo-China is of equal importance to them because, for the time being at any rate, it is destroying the effectiveness of the granary of Asia. I do not make these statements in criticism of what the Minister for External Affairs is doing. I know that he is free from any illusions about the scope of the decisions that were made at the recent conference in Sydney. However, I remind the House that there are means open to us by which we can foster joint enterprises for the purpose of restoring order in the Irrawaddy Valley and the Mekong Valley and that such enterprises would be of much greater importance than the decisions of the Sydney conference. Apart from that, no exception can be taken to the decisions of the conference. The sending of technical officers to Asia, the continuance of the training of Asiatic students in Australia, and the granting of financial assistance for the restoration of industry are policies that the Opposition endorses. In fact, the. Labour Government's representatives agreed to them in principle at the Economic Commission for Asia and the Par East and the United Nations. Of course, if Dr. Soekarno continues to press his demand for territory in western New Guinea, it would be a mistake for Australia to ignore him and to continue to speak about granting economic aid to Indonesia as though the affront to our interests, policy and needs made no difference to the effort that we were prepared to direct to his country's reconstruction. However, I arn sure that the Minister will not make such a mistake. I merely mention this aspect of the situation in order to show that we, on this side of the House, have considered it.

The decisions of the Sydney conference were humane. They were valuable because they brought together representatives of the British Commonwealth of Nations. They were particularly valuable because they produced the endorsement by two Asiatic countries - India and Ceylon - of a plan for the reconstruction of Asia. 'That achievement in itself was admirable. Ceylon may be regarded as being a relatively well-off Asiatic country, but India has had very great struggles to reconstruct itself and the fact that it is willing to shoulder some part of the burdens of South-East Asia is entirely commendable. I am. very glad that the Minister was instrumental in calling the conference at which India made that decision. Although the decisions of the conference were of limited value, they were at least an earnest of Australia's concern for the well-being of its neighbours and eagerness to assist world reconstruction. "We must make sure, of course, that none of the proposed economic aid is misapplied. The decisions of the conference represent a continuation of the policy that was pursued by the Labour Government, which subscribed heavily to world relief through Unrra and by other means. That Government unfortunately witnessed the failure of a part of its aid policy in Asia. It is no criticism of the former Minister for External Affairs, the Chifley Government, or its advisers, to say that much of Australia's Unrra, aid to China went down the drain. We must protect ourselves against such eventualities when giving aid in Asia. We must ensure that the governments that we help are capable of using to the best advantage the technical materials that we provide. However, I am sure that the Minister and his advisers will have such possibilities constantly in mind. The decisions of the Sydney conference represented a logical continuation of the policy of world relief and reconstruction that was pursued by the Chifley Government. For that reason, and also for their intrinsic decency and humanity, I warmly support them.

talk.start.para: . - We listened to a shocking diatribe from the honorable member for East Sydney (M'r. Ward), who tried to prove, from his own sources of information, which presumably include the Tribune, that the Malayan situation had been caused by the poverty of the people of that country. That situation is one of the most serious that confront Aus.ralia to-day, and it is advisable that we should know something about the country. I have had considerable experience in the East and in Africa, and I say without qualification that nowhere in my travels have I seen a finer colonial administration than that of Malaya. The population of Malaya consists of approximately 2,500,000 Malays, 2,500,000 immigrant Chinese and 500,000 Indians and Europeans. The indigenous peoples are happy, very gentlemanly and pleasant, and rather indolent. The British administration has had to protect them from the activities of the industrious, businesslike Chinese immigrants and it has done so very effectively. I saw very little poverty in Malaya. It was a rich country, there was full employment, and the people were happy. The administration was admirable, and I support everything that the honorable member for Chisholm (Mr. Kent Hughes) has said about it.

speech.para: Why has the terrorist movement arisen in Malaya? We know that it is not a nationalist movement. The reason is not hard to find. Malaya produces more than half the world's supply of rubber and tin. Those two commodities are vital to any defence preparations that the western democracies may be making. In whose interests are the terrorists working ? That question also can be answered without difficulty. Soviet Russia is the only nation that is disturbing the world to-day. If we examine the world strategic situation, we see that a practical stalemate exists in the "West. But there are ample opportunities for the' Soviet to expand in the East, and it is striking at the softest spots there. 'Communism is becoming stronger in the Philippines and it has already caused considerable bloodshed in Indo-China, Burma and Malaya. Why are the Communists having those successes? The reason is that the principal forces that are opposing Soviet imperialism are immobilized in Western Europe, while Russia expands in the East, in which Australia i3 so vitally concerned.

I read in the Sydney Horning Herald and in other newspapers to-day a thoughtful analysis of Russia's military forces. Frankly, the figures were staggering. Russia has vast numbers of troops, and many armoured divisions, and, from the military stand-point, has reached the highest peak in its history. Why has Russia established those forces? Is there any need for them? One now begins to understand why Russia is holding those gigantic forces in Europe. Whilst the attention of the democracies is almost wholly concentrated on them, the process of " eating away " continues in the East. The position is most serious. The honorable member for East Sydney considers that it is not serious, and that we should rely on the United Nations. So far as I am aware, the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Spender) has not at any time said anything that is detrimental to the United Nations. I take the view that if that international organization were really effective it would be working now to prevent the preparation of those vast military forces in Russia. That would be one sign to us that we could trust the United Nations. Until it shows better results than it has achieved to date, we should be guilty people if we did not take steps to defend ourselves.

What is the position in Malaya at the present time? I have a considerable knowledge of that country. The tasks that beset the British forces there are immense. Malaya has vast jungles, and open country with hills here and there. The cover that is available for guerrilla forces is excellent. The peace-loving population does not want to help the guerrillas, but as the honorable member for Chisholm said, there are methods in the East of intimidating people. I received from better sources than those from which the honorable member for East Sydney draws his information news that led me until quite recently to have grave doubts about the British methods in Malaya for dealing with the guerrillas. For jungle fighting, the finest trained troops in the world are required. It is the hardest form of fighting, and the troops who are engaged in it must be highly trained men. Anything less than the highest standard is wasted. I, personally, have had experience in two wars of bush fighting, and I know of no finer types to fight the kind of war in Malaya than Australian troops, provided they are highly trained. That is the point. Do we realize the dangers that confront us at the present time? If some Australians are aware of them, and are sufficiently patriotic to volunteer for service in Malaya, why should not the Government use them? Doubtless many Australians would realize that they were volunteering for a cause that might save this country later from infinitely worse things. To my mind, it is absolutely vital that the situation in Malaya shall be cleaned up. Communism is expanding in the East. As the Chinese regime becomes established more securely, and as communism progresses in Burma and elsewhere, the Communists will have a readymade organization in Malaya to assist them. But if the Malayan terrorists can be wiped out, the way of the Communists farther north will be made more difficult. I hope that everything will be done now to clean up that situation.

The honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Beazley) considers that the Minister for External Affairs is taking the proper stand in saying that Dutch New Guinea must remain under Dutch sovereignty. But what forces have we to back up that policy? Let us examine our economy. ! am not seeking to gain any party political advantage whatever when I say that none of us can regard the last five years without feeling a sense of discouragement. We have not succeeded in producing sufficient steel and the other materials that are required to make this country strong. Unfortunately, we have missed our opportunity in that respect. Surely, then, it behoves us, in view of the grave threat that confronts us, to remedy the situation. All honorable members are aware of how seriously the Communists are disrupting our economy, and what vital consequences their tactics may have in the next ten years. The Government has introduced legislation that is designed to prevent them from continuing those disruptive tactics and I believe that when the bill becomes law, it will be most effective in putting down a fifth column in this country. If ever the matter comes to a " showdown ", what kind of Red army will be employed in Australia? The troops would not be Europeans. They would be drawn from Asia, and Malaya is a stepping stone from that continent to Australia. The honorable member for Fremantle believes that Dr. Soekarno, the President of the United States of Indonesia, is not secure in his position. If Malaya comes under the domination of the Soviet Union and if Indonesia is insecure, the " red " menace will be brought close .to Australia. It is time for us to attend to our defences, and I support all the remarks by the honorable member for Angas (Mr. Downer) on that subject. We are a Pacific force. The Western world is thoroughly engaged with, and is completely held by, those vast military forces that Russia has produced. The Soviet has its armies ready for war, and, in addition, it has vast man-power resources in reserve. Personally, I do not think that there will be a shooting war, provided the democracies take really vigorous action against the fifth column that is operating against them. The Australian Government wishes to take that action. The honorable member for East Sydney asked, "Is it right to expend £8,000,000 on the people of Asia when there is poverty in Australia ? " The honorable gentleman expressed the opinion that that amount should be expended on social services. I wonder whether he has considered the kind of social services that would be provided in Australia if Ho Chi-minh or someother Chinese Communist leader were toconquer Australia? Do hot forget that the countries of Asia are over-populated, whilst Australia is under-populated. I seldom agree with the honorable member for Melbourne (Mr. Calwell), but I do agree entirely with his views about the necessity for increasing our population. I believe that he sees the dangers of an under-populated Australia. The Government has introduced legislation for the purpose of combating some of them. If we are to survive as a nation, we must take a realistic view of the position. We can survive, but we shall need to change our methods considerably and become more united in this country. The Government requires more assistance from the Opposition than it is receiving. I should like to compliment the Minister for External Affairs on his successful efforts at the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee on Aid to SouthEast Asia. The amount of £8,000,000 to assist the progress of South-East Asia is not a large sum, but the provision of it represents a beginning in the right direction. Before that, we heard only talk. Once a start is made, and the movement receives encouragement, we shall succeed. We should try very hard to ensure that success.

talk.start.para: . - The Liberal party and the Australian Country party, when they were in opposition, frequently criticized the policy of the Labour Government in sending- the then Minister for External Affairs, Dr. Evatt, and other Ministers abroad for the purpose of representing Australia at international conferences. I have always believed that this country should participate in international conferences, because valuable personal contacts are made between the delegates from the various countries who attend them. Those countries may not always have the same ideals, hut they often have the same objectives in view at the conferences. However, the Labour Government encountered some -violent opposition from members of the Liberal party and the Australian Country party when it sent representatives abroad for discussions on subjects similar to those that were considered by the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee on Aid to South-East Asia. The mathematical record shows clearly that the Labour Government did more to help other countries, including the United Kingdom when it was in a desperate position, than any other government has done in the history of Australia. Spectacular results may not immediately follow the conference of the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee, but I believe that the contacts that are made between the representatives of various nations that attend such conferences are most valuable.

speech.para: Why is the British Commonwealth taking so much interest in the economic welfare of Eastern peoples ? We may well pose that question to ourselves. Are we inspired by humanitarian motives? Are we practising the ideals of Christianity by helping the less fortunate peoples? Or are we showing that interest in them for some utilitarian motive? Honorable members should ponder those questions, because for many centuries the Western World' has not taken any interest in the plight of the people of Asia, millions of whom, have died from starvation. To-day, however, Australia and other nations are displaying a keen interest in the economic welfare of the Eastern peoples. Why are they doing so? Perhaps I may be permitted to digress a little to say that I am told that, although we hear a great deal in this House about communism., and anybody who has been associated with the Communists is denounced, the subject of communism was hardly mentioned at the conferences that were held in Sydney and Baguio.

talk.start.para: - They did not have to mention it.

- I am glad that the honorable member for Gippsland (Mr. Bowden) has made that interjection. Why was it not necessary to mention communism at those conferences? The Government and its supporters constantly warn the Parliament of the grave danger that is flowing towards Australia from the continent of Asia. Yet the delegates from some of the countries that were represented at those conferences are already collaborating with Communist governments in other countries.
- Which ones?

- I shall cite two instances. In another speech, I recalled that the present Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies), when he was Leader of the Opposition, subjected Dr. Soekarno, who is the President of the United States of Indonesia, to grave abuse. The Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Spender) joined in that attack.
- Is he not the fellow I "slobbered" over?

- That is right. It was then claimed that Dr. Soekarno was a Communist and had collaborated with the Japanese. Has Dr. Soekarno completely changed his spots? The Labour Government did not share those views about him, because we had been told by people like Lord Killearn, Lord Inverchapel and Lord Mountbatten that the real force behind the Indonesian revolution against the Dutch was nationalism. In view of those expressions of opinion by men who knew their subject, or who should have known their subject, we were not prepared to accept offhand the statements that were made by members of the then Opposition to the effect that Dr. Hatta, Dr. Sjahrir and Dr. Soekarno were inclined towards the Communists, or had collaborated with the Japanese. We did not accept that view because we had the word of other persons that nationalism was the great stirring motive in the events in Indonesia. However, I read this week that Dr. Hatta, who is the Prime Minister of the United States of Indonesia, had publicly intimated the likelihood that his government would open negotiations with, or would establish diplomatic relations with Ho. Chi-minh, the leader of the socalled Communists, although some people call them nationalists in Indo-China. I was astonished that the Australian press did not report the following news item which was broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation : -

quote.para: The Burmese Premier, Mr. Thakin Nu, who is on his way to Rangoon from London, said in Calcutta yesterday that his Government is negotiating with Communist China, Soviet Russia, and the East European countries to establish diplomatic relations by the exchange of Ambassadors.

speech.para: I do not wish.' to discuss the internal situation in Burma. No doubt the Minister knows something about it and is aware that it is not at all satisfactory. Last year I took an opportunity to examine thoroughly the facts that were placed before me regarding the situation in that country. I do not believe that any one would be satisfied with it or with the history of the leading political parties in Burma. In Indo-China we find that although our allies are giving full support ito the Government of Bao Dai, that Government has entered into agreements with the so-called Communists in China for the exchange of goods as well as other arrangements relating to currency and dollars. We must face up frankly to these issues, because it is useless for us to deceive ourselves about them. I shall not discuss the internal position in the Philippines except to say that anybody who knows anything about the position in that country cannot feel happy about the present administration there and the influences that are at work in that country. The Hukballahap movement in the Philippines is rapidly gaining ground. I suppose that any one who disagrees with the Huk.ballahaps will say that they are Communists, because it is the fashion to describe persons with whom we do not agree as Communists or fascists. The position that exists in the Philippines at present is, indeed, perilous.

The honorable member for Chisholm "(Mr. Kent Hughes) appears to think that all these problems will be solved once law and order is restored; but the restoration of law and order in many countries, particularly eastern countries, has not saved millions from dying of starvation. We have evinced concern about these problems only when movements of the kind to which all honorable members have referred have stirred us to action. I am not concerned about what stirs us into action, so long as we have at last a recognition of the fact that the real cause of trouble in the world is misery and poverty among the masses. On that aspect, I cannot cite a better authority than His Holiness the Pope. I quote the following from a press report that was published only last Sunday : -

quote.para: The Pope told a meeting of the International Social Study Congress in Rome yesterday that the world must take off its blinkers and squarely face the problems that threatened to cause a third world war. He appealed for world-wide action to end unemployment and social misery which, he said, were the primary causes of international unrest.

speech.para: I do not think that the position could be summed up in a better way. The honorable member for Chisholm seems to think that if law and order is restored at the point of a gun or under the supervision of troops, perfection will be achieved and all unrest will be stopped. That is not correct. Unrest continued in India, Burma and Indonesia in spite of the threat of guns-

talk.start.para: - But not in Malaya.

- I shall deal with the situation in Malaya about which the honorable member for Chisholm and the honorable member for Hume (Mr. Charles Anderson) had something to say. Last year I had the opportunity to travel through Johore State and to talk to the many people there. I was told by persons in authority in that region that prior to the outbreak of the recent war there was complete exploitation of the rubber tappers in Malaya. Any one who requires physical evidence of the misery that exists in Malaya need only visit Singapore and see the palaces that have been built, since the end of the war, in one section of that city and in another section, Chinatown, the indescribable misery in which hundreds of thousands of people are obliged to live. That evidence is irrefutable. What is the problem in Malaya? The honorable member for Chisholm said that many Malayans were being stampeded into supporting the terrorists. How does he account for the fact - and the figure is official- that 500,000 Chinese in that country have squatted on land that does not belong to them ? Nobody induced those Chinese to break the law in that way merely by intimidating them. In the Philippines 99 per cent, of the land is owned by only 1 per cent, of the population of that country. The fact is that half the population of Malaya, including Singapore, is Chinese who are antagonistic to the Malayans, and vice versa. Between those two sections are sandwiched from 600,000 to 700,000 Indians. Beal peace will never be established in Malaya unless a government is formed in that country which will bring together those sections to work in harmony for their common good. Of course, it is useless to argue that the Chinese in Malaya are not more industrious, intelligent or commercially minded than, the Malayans. Something must be done for the less fortunate sections of the people in that country. I am entirely in sympathy with any action that the Government proposes to take for the purpose provided that it be taken with the right motives and not for purely material motives. I agree with the view expressed by Pandit Nehru that the battle against communism, or any other " ism " will not be won with guns, that it can be won only by capturing the spirit of the people whose lot we are trying to improve. Because Pandit Nehru fought for his ideals, he spent twelve years in gaol ; but, to-day, the world seeks to do him honour. Only a few days ago, when he visited Djakarta, he was greeted in the steets of that city by over 50,000 people. Yet, not so long ago, he was gaoled for subversive activities; and we have heard ii great deal lately about activities so-called.

speech.para: The Opposition wishes to join with the Government in its plan to assist the unfortunate peoples of South and SouthEast Asia, but only if the action proposed to be taken is inspired by a spirit of humanitarianism. We can help to raise the standard of living of those peoples by various means, including the provision of technical assistance and greater facilities for education. The honorable member for Chisholm rather decried the provision of assistance in that form. I do not despair of such proposals. The provision of technical equipment and facilities for technical training will do much more for the native peoples that we are anxious to help, whereas assistance in the form of monetary grants would not be effective because the money could be expended without the peoples whom it was intended to assist knowing that such grants had ever >been made. Assistance in the form of physical things is most effective particularly when 90 per cent, of these native peoples cannot read or write. When they see evidence of the assistance provided, they realize that something is being done to help them* In that way we shall also do much to stem the tide of communism which thrives under conditions of unrest, discontent and unemployment. However, any assistance that is provided, for ulterior motives will not be effective. In this matter we must be guided by the highest humanitarian ideals. The Opposition, when it was in office, persistently upheld the United Nations organization, which has already achieved much to end unrest in various countries, including. Indonesia and Israel.

I do not decry conferences of the kind for which the Minister is an advocate, but I realize the difficulties that confront such conferences in dealing with the problems of the nature of those that exist in India, South Africa, Burma or Ceylon. Excluding Australia and New Zealand, Ceylon isthe most empire-minded country in the Eastern hemisphere. It is useless merely to shout about the curse of communism. We must face up to the difficulties. If we can help the peoples of the south and south-east Asian countrieswe should do all in our power to do so, but, to repeat the view expressed by Pandit Nehru, wo shall succeed only if" we capture the spirit of the people whom we are trying to help and do not takeaction of a kind that carries with it the conviction that our real objective is toprotect certain interests in these countries so that they can continue to make a lol of dollars out of rubber, tin or otherproducts. That was the impression that was given to these native peoples in the past. To-day, we must" convince them that we are awake to the great social misery that exists in their countries about which no one bothered hitherto. Wemust convince those peoples that our only objective in helping them is to do something for humanity and for Christianity because we believe that only by working to achieve the ideals of Christianity can we improve the lot of the less fortunatepeoples of the world.

talk.start.para: . - I compliment the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Spender) upon thestatement that he has made to the House- on the subject of international affairs. I listened with some interest to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Chifley). His remarks were in keeping with the statements that we heard from him for years when he was Prime Minister and led a government that must shoulder much of the blame for the problems that have arisen in south-east Asian countries and elsewhere and with which we now seek to deal. If this problem has been handled by the Chifley Government in the manner in which it has been handled by the present Government, many of the troubles that now confront us would not exist. The Leader of the Opposition has said that communism has flourished in those countries where there is grave discontent among the people. I do not agree with him. The tenets of communism are propagated in every country of the world, including Australia,, irrespective of the social conditions of its people. The right honorable gentleman made an appeal for world action to counter the menace of communism. He views the problem as though it were not merely a matter of one country being determined to dominate the world. Australia has always been vitally concerned about the welfare of its near neighbours. It is a great pity that the Leader of the Opposition and his deputy did not show more interest in the peoples of the eastern races when they had the opportunity to do so. They must have known that the safety of British and Australian lives depended upon the maintenance of peace and con.tentment among the peoples of the East. It is lamentable that the Leader of the Opposition in this National Parliament should descend to such a low level in criticising the actions of this Government, which has done more in the short period that it has been in office to promote the welfare of the peoples of South and SouthEast Asia than his Government did throughout the long period it was in office. It is regrettable that he should attempt to fan the fires of hate by stating that the land in the Philippines is owned by only 1 per cent, of the people of that country. Such an inaccurate statement is in line with the propaganda disseminated by the Communists with the object of fomenting discontent.

speech.para: Ifr. Bernard Corser.

talk.start.para: - Does the; honorable member challenge the accuracy of that statement ?
- I have already done so.
- What I said was, that 1 per cent, of the people of that country own 99 per cent, of the land.
- Why should the Leader of the Opposition import a matter of that kind into a debate on the motion for the printing of a paper that contains no references to the Philippines ?

speech.para: In the defence of the Western democracies of Europe, the frontiers, and coasts of Spain must inevitably play a great part. It is my strong personal belief - I do not claim to speak on behalf of the Australian Country party - that in excluding Spain from, membership of the United Nations, the Western democracies acted very unwisely. In the event of a conflict in Europe, Spain would provide the logical retreat for the armies of the Western democracies in which they could recover from the first shock of attack. We should do our utmost to retract the insults of the. past and foster good relations with that country. The attitude of the Western democracies to Spain must change sooner or later,, and the sooner the better for them.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member is getting well away from the terms of the motion, which relate to a paper dealing with South and South-East Asia.

- The British Government has already recognized the Communist regime in China and the Australian Government has exchanged diplomatic representation with Russia, yet Spain, which is the greatest defensive outpost of the European nations, has been excluded from the councils of those nations which abhor communism. That country has consistently rejected the Communist philosophy and because it its creditable success in this regard it has been excluded from membership of the United Nations as the result of the pressure exerted by the Communists in France, who are members of the government of that country. The development of the latent resources of Spain would be of the greatest benefit to the Western Powers and -to Spain, and in the event of an outbreak of war in Europe would strengthen their mutual cause. They should give to that country the greatest possible assistance, because they may have to rely upon it for military aid and as an operational base for their armies should the Soviet throw out the challenge, and seek to conquer the Christian world. I feel greatly indebted to the Minister for External Affairs for the lucid statement that he has presented to the House on the problems that confront this country. Honorable members, and the people generally, will regard it as most valuable. I have pleasure in supporting the motion.

. - I regret that the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Corser) completely misunderstood the purport of the remarks of the Leader of tie Opposition (Mr. Chifley) . The right honorable gentleman said, in effect, that communism has made its greatest progress and brought about the direst results in countries in which the living standards of the people are very low, and social discontent, is rife. That statement is perfectly true. I invite the honorable member for Wide Bay to compare the conditions in countries in which communism has made rapid, headway with those that exist in countries in which communism has been kept at bay. If he did so, he would find that, in the United States of America, Sweden, Norway, and the British Commonwealth, in which the conditions of life are good, communism has made least progress, but that in the countries in which the greatest poverty and misery exists, communism has flourished and is still flourishing. I agree with the honorable gentleman that the statement by the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Spender) is most valuable, and has been of great assistance not only to the members of this House but also to the Australian community. It reveals that great problems are facing the countries of South and South-East Asia, that they must have some effect on Australia, and that they have resulted from unfavorable social and economic conditions among the peoples concerned. These conditions, .as he has very rightly pointed out, should be corrected and it is the duty of all the more advanced nations to assist in some way or other in providing the necessary impetus for the rectification of the conditions that have placed South and South-East Asia in the very difficult position in which they are to-day. That is very necessary because those areas, despite the fact that they constitute only one-fifth of the earth's surface, contain half the world's population. The conditions that have gradually developed in those countries since 1945, moving down through China, India and Burma into Malaya and Indonesia, show that during the period in which we had hoped that the nations of the world would be able to recover from the disastrous effects of the war, those countries have encountered difficulties and problems that up to the present they have not been able to solve. This conference has produced constructive suggestions regarding steps that might be taken to improve the conditions of the peoples of those countries. I consider that it is essential that certain matters should be pointed out to honorable members. In every one of these countries we find similar difficulties that might be summed up in the facts that populations are growing, standards of living are deteriorating, general illiteracy and primitive methods of production exist, and production is low. In addition those countries suffer from poor hygiene and a very high mortality rate. Since the war a number of Asian countries have attained self-government, and as a result have realized the backward nature of their own economic and social development more clearly than they did before. They have found it necessary, in co-operation with other countries and among themselves to try to find ways and means of making life better in their own particular spheres. That is a very difficult undertaking because most of those countries are mainly agricultural. Their economic life depends upon the soil. In India, which might be taken as typical of most Asian countries, 70 per cent, of the population depend upon agriculture for their livelihood, and only 11 per cent, secure a livelihood from industry or handicrafts. However, in spite of the fact that such a large proportion of the people of India work on the land it is rapidly becoming evident that because of the general unsettlement of conditions and the internal unrest in that country it is unable to provide all the food that is required for its own people or any surplus for export to other Asian countries that would enable them to meet their difficulties. Because of these factors the Minister's recommendations regarding the provision of economic, technical and financial aid to Asian countries become understandable and we can realize that unless effect is given to them the position may become more desperate, with very disastrous reactions upon this country.

speech.para: One aspect of the matter that has not been- dealt with during this debate and that I consider all honorable members should note is that the whole responsibility of trying to solve these internal difficulties of Asian countries does not fall alone upon the United Nations or upon a conference of members or of other bodies that may be called to discuss them. In 1944, at the International Labour Organization conference that was held at Philadelphia, the whole subject of assistance to Asiatic and South Asiatic countries was given very earnest consideration. That conference was called for the purpose of determining the policy to be adopted in regard to the improvement of the conditions of the masses in those countries following the conclusion of World War II., which was then raging. One of the decisions made was that it was necessary that the International Labour Organization should itself take steps to enable better conditions to operate in the backward countries of the world. Among other things it was determined that at the earliest possible moment regional conferences should be called in Asia and amongst the Asian peoples, so that the problems of the Asian nations might be considered. That was an important decision because it meant that if such conferences were held under the auspices of the International Labour Organization the three constituent parties in the modern State would be asked to co-operate in order to deal with problems facing the Asian nations. As is well known, all the representation at the International Labour Organization Conference is of a tri-partite nature. It consists of representatives of governments, employers and workers of the participating nations. These three important constituents in the State meet together to consider the problems that are common to all of them and te make recommendations concerning how those problems might be overcome. The 1944 conference decided that the first regional conference should he a conference of the Asiatic countries that were represented at that conference. Those countries advanced the plea that the Asian countries that lie close to one another would have a mutual understanding of their common problems. They were entirely different from the problems found in the Western world. It was considered that if the delegations consisting of representatives of ' governments, employers and workers met something might be achieved that would improve the conditions of life of the Asian masses. The first regional conference convened by the International Labour Organization was held at New Delhi in 1947 and the very matters that have been the subject of considerable comment and explanation by the Minister for External Affairs were in fact discussed there by the representatives of employers, governments and workers. At that preliminary conference these matters were set down for discussion. The necessary machinery was put into operation to ascertain the facts in connexion with the proposals advanced, and arrangements were made for a further conference to be held. The preliminary conference covered increased production, development of agriculture, the development of handicrafts, the formation' of co-operative societies, social security, recruiting and training of workers, wages and the protection of women and young workers. Subsequently, in February of this year, following the conference of British Commonwealth ministers held at Ceylon, a second regional conference to deal with the conditions in Asia was convened by the International Labour Organization and was held at Ceylon. It was attended by representatives of the same number of nations as had attended the New Delhi Conference in 1947. Eighteen nations were represented ranging from Indonesia in the south to China in the north. One hundred and twenty-one delegates from those countries represented their governments, employers and workers. They were able to make more progress in connexion with the problems that affected the countries that we are now discussing. That conference realized that if the best results were to be obtained for the improvement of the productive capacity of the Asian nations, illiteracy had to be wiped out. The honorable member for Chisholm (Mr. Kent Hughes) stressed very rightly what was being done in Malaya in regard to education, but that position does not operate in all the other countries that were associated with the International Labour Conference at Ceylon. The delegates to that conference realized that the problem of illiteracy must be tackled in such a manner as to enable people to get at least some elementary education without which the development of handicrafts and industry would be impossible. Decisions were made on such important matters as the establishment of wage-fixing machinery, measures designed to improve Asian Labour Inspection services, international action to stimulate development of the co-operative movement as a means to further economic development, measures designed to assist Asian countries to make full use of their man-power through the organization and development of employment services, and the provision of vocational and technical training. The request was made that the governing body of the International Labour Organization should soon convene a further conference to discuss conditions affecting Asian seamen. I think that the essential point in connexion with that conference is that the people who are to provide the machinery to increase the production rate and the standards of living, and to do the other things that are necessary to overcome the internal discontent in those countries, have taken the required action and have passed the necessary resolutions. Governments and organizations of employers and workers are committed to carrying out a policy that is designed to bring about internal im provements. A continuation of that kind of action is the quickest way of overcoming the difficulties in Asiatic countries:

I conclude by saying that the decisions at that conference were real and practical. I agree with the honorable member for Chisholm that in giving technical aid of some description to increase production in these countries it is impossible to have them jump from lowly methods of production to highly mechanized methods. To the Asian farmer who has to stand- on his plough in order to break the soil, the provision of tractors and other highly mechanized equipment is of no use at all. The thing to do is to provide him with better hand tools, with a spade to use instead of his hands, with rakes and hoes to break up the soil, with pumps instead of buckets- and cans. By such means we can rapidly improve the productivity of the Asian countries. Better seed could be made available to Asian farmers and they could be taught how to use and preserve the soil. That is what is required to meet the problems of production and low standards of living and to enable Asian farmers to get the best results from their toil. If the Asian people, in cooperation with one another, do their best to assist themselves, if the highly developed nations make available to the governments of those countries the technical advice that can assist them in big projects, and if the efforts that are now being made to overcome illiteracy are continued, in a very short space of time a lot of the difficulties that now confront the South Asian and Asian people will probably be overcome because of the application of common sense to the problems of those countries by the nations that help them.

talk.start.para: .- There was a discussion in this House recently on a matter that was raised hy the honorable member for Corangamite (Mr. McDonald), concerning a broadcast which had been made by a Mr. Frank Browne. At that time I asked the Postmaster-General (Mr. Anthony) what action he proposed to take in regard to the employment by the Australian Broadcasting Commission of Frank Browne as a writer of script. I notice that no such action appears to have been taken, because in the programme from 2FC-2NA on the 13th June, at 8 o'clock, there is an item that is listed as, " The race called the Derby : Feature by Frank Browne ". I should like the Minister to say whether Mr. Browne is presenting this item in completion of a contract that he has with the Australian Broadcasting Commission or whether he is being favorably considered for work of this type. In view of the charge that was made against Mr. Frank Browne by the honorable member for Corangamite, and in view of many other things that could' be said by honorable members regarding his activities, T suggest that he is not a fit and proper person to be employed by the Australian Broadcasting Commission or any other government department, and I ask the Minister in charge of the House (Mr. Spender) to take the matter up with the Postmaster-General in order to see whether he can obtain a statement on it.

speech.para: I wish also to speak on the subject of housing. From time to time, when disastrous floods take place, appeals are made for some assistance to be given to the persons affected and, quite properly, the governments of the country, and the Commonwealth Government in particular, assist in alleviating their distress. When a very few people are affected there does not seem to be the same agitation to render assistance, and my appeal is on behalf of a number of people who have been affected by the recent heavy rains in the metropolitan area of .Sydney. These unfortunate people, who have been living in emergency accommodation, such as tents in coastal camping areas, particularly in the Narrabeen district, were completely washed out by the recent torrential rains and an appeal was made by the New South Wales police to the New South Wales Housing Commission for some assistance in temporarily housing them until they could be provided for elsewhere. The police were informed by the housing authorities that no emergency accommodation was available. Quite a number of families are affected and, no doubt, in other areas the position is just as desperate. Many of them have young families and I want to know whether this Government will make accommodation available for housing them by treating the present situation as one of emergency. No doubt there are military establishments at which some accommodation could be made available and blankets and warm clothing could be provided as well. Unless something is done for these people they will be unable to extricate themselves from their desperate plight. The police have been unable to give aid and the State housing authorities say that they are unable to help. The only authority remaining to be approached is the Commonwealth. Surely some accommodation could be made available in the service establishments of the Commonwealth. Victoria Barracks at Paddington has a great deal of accommodation, much of which, 1 understand, is used for storing records which could be shifted elsewhere so that the space thus occupied might be used to accommodate these families that are in such distressing circumstances. However, it is not my purpose to advise the Government as to where the accommodation can be found because I am not in possession of sufficient information on that subject to enable me to do so. Itshould be the responsibility of some authority to help these people. As they have failed to obtain assistance elsewhere I want to know what the Commonwealth is prepared to do for them.

talk.start.para: . - I consider that before the House adjourns something should be said concerning certain honours and awards that the conferring of which has been announced to-day. If I mention any names in that list, it is not for the purpose of comparing them in any way with others, but merely to emphasize my remarks. Ex-servicemen will feel considerable satisfaction that the names of the people concerned should have appeared in the list. By way of example, I refer to such distinguished gentlemen as LieutenantGeneral Sir BE. C. H. Robertson, who has maintained and enhanced the prestige of this country by his command of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force in Japan; Lieutenant-General Sir Stanley Savige, whose campaign on Bougainville was a_very considerable feat of arms, and who rendered distinguished service there and elsewhere; and Brigadier Sir Neil Hamilton Fairley, whose researches into the problem of malaria were responsible for the fact that the Australian Army was able to continue fighting in malarious areas and whose work in the experimental station that was established at Cairns was a great contribution not only to military medicine, but also to the world's knowledge of malaria. The contributions made by Sir Neil Hamilton Fairley were so notable in this case that he is now Professor of Tropical Medicine in the University of London. Malaria, I point out, kills more people every year than does any other infectious disease in the world, not even excepting tuberculosis.

speech.para: Above all, I should like to mention the award to Field-Marshal Sir Thomas Blarney, who is a distinguished soldier of two world wars. Many of us exservicemen, as time rolled on, experienced a feeling of disappointment - I might almost say dismay - because no recognition had been accorded to the distinguished soldier who commanded the Australian Army from the time the nation's life was at stake until final victory was won. I know that the reward of a soldier does not consist of, and is not measured by, the honours and awards that he may receive. The reward of a soldier, I suggest, is the knowledge that he has performed his duty to his country and made his contribution to the preservation of the national life, and if there is any soldier in Australia who can feel entitled to that reward it is Sir Thomas Blarney. It is a right as well as a tradition of our race, that at the end of a war - and I point out that the last war was the greatest in all history - some mark of national esteem should be accorded to the leaders of the armed forces. In his case that has now been done, and the act of doing it has given satisfaction to all ex-servicemen. Not only does this award mark the nation's gratitude to a distinguished soldier, but also it recalls, if, indeed, there were any need to recall it, the memory of all those who served under his command and whose mortal remains now lie in the cemeteries of the western desert, in Greece, Crete, and in the jungles and forests of the islands north of Australia. It recalls, also, all those in this country who bear in their bodies the marks and infirmities of war. "Whilst we can express our appreciation of the distinction that has been accorded to Field-Marshal Blarney, I invite the attention of the Minister at the table (Mr. Spender) to the desirability of some national recognition of the services of other military leaders. We owe a great debt also to the leaders of the naval and air forces of the Commonwealth. I have in mind, too, another distinguished soldier, who served for two periods as Chief of the Australian General Staff, and who commanded the First Australian Army when it was fighting in New Guinea, New Britain and Bougainville, and when, T consider, the Australian military effort reached its peak. That Army fought in military circumstances of great novelty and considerable magnitude, and I suggest that national figures such as its leader should not be allowed to pass finally into the shadows without some mark of esteem from the nation that they served so well.

talk.start.para: .- 1 associate myself with the remarks of the honorable member for Oxley (Dr. Donald Cameron). As most honorable members are aware, the Labour party is opposed to the conferring of military and civil honours. However, when such honours are conferred, I am always prepared to pay my tribute to the recipients. On this occasion, so far as I am aware from a rapid perusal of the honours list, the awards are well merited. A regrettable feature of the practice of conferring honours is that, inevitably, some deserving individuals are omitted from the list because they are forgotten or overlooked. As far as military honours are concerned, I regret that they cannot be made to every member of the forces. However, I rose principally to express my gratification at the promotion of General Blarney to the rank of Field Marshal. I have always considered that General Blarney had a profound knowledge of tactics and strategy and the capacity to put that knowledge to very good use. In my opinion, during the 1914-18 war, there was a long period of time during which men were needlessly sacrificed. I have always believed that from the time General Blarney became Chief of Staff of the Australian Army Corps under Sir John Monash there was a great improvement of tactics and strategy, with a consequent saving of many lives. I believe, too, that General Blarney's military knowledge played a great part in "World War II. For those reasons, I consider that the honour that has been conferred upon this distinguished soldier is well merited and will meet with full approval.

.- I associate myself completely .with the expressions of gratification that have been made by honorable members about the honours list. However, I wish also to ask the House to direct its attention to a more prosaic and. domestic matter.

speech.para: I do not think that this debate should be allowed to conclude without some reference being made to the remarks of the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) about the Australian Broadcasting Commission's use of scripts written by Frank Browne. About Frank Browne's journalistic work, I have nothing to say. I have occasionally seen copies of his news sheet and, from what I have read in it, I see no reason to attempt to dispute the remarks of honorable members on this side of the House about his standard of journalism. However, the honorable member for East Sydney has suggested that, merely because he has asked questions and expressed opinions in this House concerning Frank Browne's standard of journalism, the Australian Broadcasting Commission should immediately cease broadcasting his work. That, I believe, would amount to an unwarranted interference with the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. As an independent statutory body, the Australian Broadcasting Commission has a right and a duty to carry out its responsibilities in its own way. The suggestion that it should be immediately influenced by a question asked, or an opinion expressed by an honorable member of this House is, to my mind, quite unreasonable.

talk.start.para: .- It is not often that honorable members on both sides of this House are able to express similar sentiments on any subject that comes up for discussion. So, when that happens the occasion is indeed noteworthy. It is most gratifying that honorable members opposite, through the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard), are able to express their wholehearted support of the Government's action in raising General Blarney to the v rank of Field Marshal. This is a great honour for the former leader of the Australian Military Forces, and the occasion is one on which there should be rejoicing not only among men and women who served under General Blarney during the war, but also among all Australians. The number of field marshals in the history of the British Empire is limited, and it is a source of great satisfaction that that honour should have been conferred upon an Australian who' has risen through the ranks by his own ability and nothing else. My only regret is that General Blarney was not given this recognition earlier, and that he was not called to. the bar of this House so that the representatives of the people could express to him something of the debt that I know every Australian must sincerely believe that we all owe to this great Australian. In saying that, I do not wish to reflect on any action that this Government or the previous Government took or failed to take. The honorable member for Lalor has made it clear that members of the Labour party are opposed to the granting of honours. Although I do not agree with that view, it is a reasonable one, and I respect it. The attitude of the Labour party has always been made clear. As the conferring of this honour upon General Blarney represents an official compliment to that distinguished soldier by the Government, it is not for private members to embroider the gesture. Indeed, there is very little that we can say, but I should like to add a word or two as one who, in a very humble capacity, had the honour to serve under General Blamey. The granting of this honour is a source of great satisfaction, not only to me, but also to hundreds of thousands of men and women in this country. Wherever he went during the war, even in times of great crisis, he radiated confidence and by his own personal resolution, inspired the men and women of this country to greater endeavours. In that way he played a decisive role in the effort that the country was able to put forward. The honour that has been conferred on him is a very high one, but I suggest that the real memorial of this great Australian will not be in anything that this Parliament or this Government can offerhim, but it will be in the fact that in this country to-day there are many thousands and perhaps tens of thousands of splendid young Australians who would not be alive were it not for the leadership of Sir Thomas Blamey in times of stress. Throughout the war, from start to finish, he employed the men of this countryin the most sparing way and in the way in which they could be best employed. Whenever any question arose of unnecessary casualties being suffered or anything of that nature Sir Thomas Blamey clearly showed that hehad the interests of the forces underhis command very close to his heart. That I believe was his guiding principle, and therefore it gives me very great pleasure to commend the Government's action inhonouring him in this way.

.- I should like to supplement the remarks thathave been made about thehonours list published to-day. Therehas been a lot of talk about field marshals, generals, eminent surgeons and so on, whohave receivedhonours. I want to devote a minute or so to speaking on behalf of one of the more humble recipients mentioned in thehonours list. In saying that I am reminded of Masefield's famous lines -

quote.para: Not of the princes and prelates with periwigged charioteers,
Riding triumphantly laurelled to lap the fat of the years;
But rather the scorned and rejected . . .

speech.para: I wish to mention a very gallant group of Australian women, the war widows. Those of us who have tried to do what we can for themin our own humble way, have been impressed by their sacrifice, struggle and gallantry. In the honours list to-day appeared the name of Mrs. Vasey, a woman who has carried on a magnificent fight on behalf of the war widows of Australia. I commend the honour bestowed uponher, not because it is a recognition ofher services, but because it is an honour bestowed through her on the gallant war widows of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
